dimensions.name: sleep_duration
dimensions.description: Estimated hours of sleep, proxied by gap between last evening activity and first morning activity next day
dimensions.how_to_measure: Derived from bedtime_hour and next day's morning_wake_hour: (morning_wake_hour + 24 - bedtime_hour) mod 24, yielding hours of estimated sleep
dimensions._changed: aggregation: last→mean, how_to_measure: clarified as derived variable with explicit formula and units (hours)

dimensions.name: bedtime_hour
dimensions.description: Hour of day when last browsing activity occurred, serving as proxy for bedtime
dimensions.how_to_measure: Identify all browsing event timestamps for the day; extract the hour (0-23) of the latest timestamp, adding 24 if after midnight (e.g., 2am = 26). Units: hours on 0-28 scale.
dimensions._changed: aggregation: last→max, how_to_measure: clarified timestamp selection and extended hour scale with units

dimensions.name: morning_wake_hour
dimensions.description: Hour of first browsing activity in the morning, proxy for wake time
dimensions.how_to_measure: Identify all browsing event timestamps after 05:00 for the day; extract the hour (5-23) of the earliest timestamp. Units: hours on 5-23 scale.
dimensions._changed: aggregation: first→min, how_to_measure: clarified timestamp selection with units

dimensions.name: evening_screen_time
dimensions.description: Volume of browsing activity between 6pm and midnight, measuring pre-sleep screen engagement
dimensions.how_to_measure: Count the number of distinct browsing events (searches or page visits) with timestamps between 18:00 and 23:59
dimensions._changed: measurement_dtype: continuous→count, how_to_measure: changed from 'minutes based on timestamp gaps' (per-unit enumeration) to counting discrete events

dimensions.name: late_night_activity_count
dimensions.description: Number of browsing actions after midnight, indicating insomnia or delayed sleep
dimensions.how_to_measure: Count browsing events (searches or page visits) with timestamps between 00:00 and 04:59

dimensions.name: cognitive_load_evening
dimensions.description: Intensity of mentally demanding content browsed in evening hours before sleep
dimensions.how_to_measure: Count browsing events between 18:00-23:59 where content involves: programming languages, algorithms, cryptography, security, mathematics, academic papers, technical documentation, or complex problem-solving

dimensions.name: work_intensity_daily
dimensions.description: Amount of work-related technical browsing throughout the day reflecting occupational demands
dimensions.how_to_measure: Count browsing events where content involves: programming languages (Haskell, Python, etc.), code repositories, Stack Overflow, technical documentation, software tools, APIs, or work communication platforms

dimensions.name: health_anxiety_searches
dimensions.description: Searches related to health concerns, medical conditions, symptoms indicating health worry
dimensions.how_to_measure: Count search queries or page visits containing: disease names, symptom descriptions, medication side effects, medical conditions, diagnosis terms, or health forum discussions

dimensions.name: substance_interest
dimensions.description: Searches related to psychoactive substances, medications, or nootropics that may affect sleep
dimensions.how_to_measure: Count browsing events involving: specific substance names (ketamine, piracetam, modafinil, etc.), drug effect discussions, dosing information, pharmacology, or substance-focused subreddits/forums

dimensions.name: travel_activity
dimensions.description: Searches related to travel planning, destinations, flights, hotels indicating potential timezone disruption
dimensions.how_to_measure: Count browsing events involving: flight booking sites, hotel searches, destination names in travel context, travel weather queries, visa/passport information, currency conversion, or roaming/international phone plans

dimensions.name: sleep_related_searches
dimensions.description: Searches specifically about sleep, sleep trackers, or sleep problems indicating sleep concerns
dimensions.how_to_measure: Count browsing events containing: sleep, insomnia, circadian, melatonin, sleep tracker brands (Oura, Dreem, Whoop), sleep apnea, RDI, sleep hygiene, or sleep disorder terms

dimensions.name: browsing_topic_diversity
dimensions.description: Variety of different topic categories browsed in a day, indicating scattered attention or restlessness
dimensions.how_to_measure: Classify each browsing event into one category from: {technology, travel, health, entertainment, food, finance, news, shopping, social, music, sports, academic, other}. Record the category for each event.
dimensions._changed: measurement_dtype: count→categorical, aggregation: sum→n_unique, how_to_measure: specified explicit category set instead of counting

dimensions.name: is_weekend
dimensions.description: Whether the day is Saturday or Sunday, affecting schedule flexibility
dimensions.how_to_measure: From any timestamp on that day, extract day of week. Code 1 if Saturday or Sunday, 0 if Monday-Friday.

dimensions.name: underlying_stress
dimensions.description: Latent stress level inferred from behavioral patterns like health searches, late night activity, topic switching

dimensions.name: circadian_regularity
dimensions.description: Variability of sleep timing over the past week, with higher values indicating more irregularity
dimensions.how_to_measure: Collect the bedtime_hour values from each of the past 7 days. Units: standard deviation in hours.
dimensions._changed: how_to_measure: removed 'Calculate standard deviation' (computation belongs in aggregation), clarified raw input and units

dimensions.name: arousing_content_evening
dimensions.description: Stimulating or emotionally activating content consumed in evening hours
dimensions.how_to_measure: Count browsing events between 18:00-23:59 involving: news articles, political content, controversial discussions, thriller/horror entertainment, competitive gaming, or emotionally charged social media threads

dimensions.name: total_daily_browsing
dimensions.description: Overall browsing volume for the day indicating general activity level
dimensions.how_to_measure: Count all browsing events (searches and page visits) occurring on that calendar day

edges.description: Later bedtime directly reduces available sleep time before morning obligations or natural wake time
Blue light exposure and mental engagement from evening screens suppresses melatonin and delays sleep onset
More screen time in evening leads to later bedtime through engagement and blue light alerting effects
Complex mental work in evening keeps mind active and engaged, delaying sleep onset
Mental stimulation before bed causes racing thoughts and difficulty falling asleep
Emotionally stimulating content increases alertness and delays transition to sleep
Arousing content before bed increases physiological arousal that impairs sleep quality
Activity after midnight directly cuts into potential sleep time
High work demands during day create spillover into evening work and technical browsing
Intensive work demands increase psychological stress and arousal levels
Work demands extend screen usage into evening hours
Stress causes rumination, hyperarousal, and cortisol elevation that impairs sleep initiation and maintenance
Stress and anxiety manifest as difficulty stopping browsing, rumination, and insomnia-driven activity
Underlying stress manifests as somatic focus and health-related worry driving medical searches
Stress-driven hyperarousal delays ability to wind down and go to sleep
Health-related searches can amplify worry and catastrophizing, increasing stress in feedback loop
Health worry directly impairs sleep through rumination about symptoms and conditions
Searching about sleep problems indicates and potentially amplifies sleep-related anxiety
Weekends allow later bedtimes without morning work obligations
Work-related browsing is typically reduced on weekends
Without work obligations, weekends allow sleeping in later
Travel planning creates excitement and logistical stress that elevates arousal
Active travel planning and potential timezone anticipation disrupts normal sleep patterns
Scattered attention across many unrelated topics may indicate restlessness or inability to focus from stress
Diverse browsing requires more cognitive switching and mental engagement
Interest in psychoactive substances may indicate attempts to self-manage stress or mood problems
Substance use or contemplation of use may directly affect sleep physiology and worry
Poor sleep increases next-day stress reactivity, emotional dysregulation, and cognitive difficulty
Sleep duration influences natural wake time through sleep pressure and circadian interaction
Poor sleep reduces next-day cognitive capacity, potentially reducing work output or increasing compensatory effort
Irregular sleep schedule weakens circadian entrainment leading to poorer sleep quality and duration
Daily bedtime variation feeds into weekly circadian regularity measure
Higher overall daily browsing activity tends to extend into evening hours
Very high browsing volume may indicate restlessness, procrastination, or stress-driven distraction
